title: Big Ten basketball notebook | Less time for athletes is ‘a joke,’ Izzo says | Buckeye Xtra Sports
text:
>> Get the most out of your Ohio State experience, follow @BuckeyeXtra on Twitter 
Michigan State men’s basketball coach Tom Izzo is no fan of the idea that college athletes should spend less time working on their sports.
“I think it’s a joke,” Izzo said at Big Ten basketball media sessions Thursday in Chicago. “Are we going to limit time on Twitter?”
Izzo always has been outspoken about the importance of his players spending extra hours to improve. But Big Ten commissioner Jim Delany and other administrators have been pushing the idea of freeing time for athletes so they could pursue more opportunities as students.
Izzo said coaches are smart enough not to “beat a kid to death” with practice, and the NCAA limits practice time anyway. His question on trying to discourage individual time spent on sports is how that time actually would be used.
“I don’t see surgeons worrying about their time,” Izzo said. “I don’t see musicians worrying about theirs. We give them more time, they get in trouble and then we get in trouble.”
Izzo also said college basketball should take a few more pages from the NBA rulebook.

“If I was the czar for the day, I’d try to get every rule like the NBA, personally,” he said.
The NCAA is instituting several rules changes and issued a directive to officials in an effort to speed up the pace of play.
One of the most notable rules changes is the reduction of the shot clock from 35 seconds to 30, a move Izzo applauds. He would not mind playing four quarters instead of two halves.
He just wants to see more similarities between the NCAA and NBA rules.
“You know, I get disappointed on the committees I’m on,” Izzo said. “I think you always hear, ‘Well, you don’t want to be like the NBA.’ Why not? That’s what the kids want.”

Ryan undecided on future Wisconsin’s Bo Ryan still is not ruling out coaching next season.
Ryan reiterated Thursday at media day that he is not ruling out coaching beyond this year, after he initially announced in June that he planned to retire at the end of the season. Two months later, he left the door open to staying on beyond that — and he is keeping it there for now.
“I haven’t made up my mind on anything other than coaching these guys,” Ryan said.
